name: Sprint Planning
description: Plan sprint goals, capacity, and backlog items for focused iteration delivery
example_output:
# Sprint 14 Planning: AI PM Workspace

## Sprint Overview
- **Sprint Duration**: 2 weeks (Feb 17 - Feb 28, 2026)
- **Sprint Goal**: Deliver the AI-powered framework recommendation engine and improve export functionality
- **Team Capacity**: 42 story points (7 engineers x 8 pts avg, minus 2 PTO days)
- **Velocity (3-sprint avg)**: 38 points

---

## Sprint Goal Statement
> By the end of this sprint, users will be able to receive AI-recommended frameworks based on their project context, and export any generated document to PDF and Markdown formats.

**Why this matters**: Framework discovery is currently manual. Users browse 45+ templates without guidance. Recommendation reduces time-to-first-output from 5 minutes to under 30 seconds. Export has been the #1 requested feature in beta feedback (mentioned by 72% of respondents).

---

## Committed Backlog Items

### High Priority (Must Complete)

| ID | Story | Points | Owner | Acceptance Criteria |
|----|-------|--------|-------|--------------------|
| PM-201 | AI framework recommender - backend | 8 | Sarah L. | Given a project description, the system returns top 3 framework matches with confidence scores above 0.7 |
| PM-202 | AI framework recommender - UI | 5 | James K. | Recommendation card displays on project dashboard; user can accept or dismiss |
| PM-203 | PDF export for generated documents | 5 | Maria C. | All framework outputs export to PDF with correct formatting, headers, and page breaks |
| PM-204 | Markdown export for generated documents | 3 | Maria C. | Export preserves all markdown syntax; file downloads with correct .md extension |

### Medium Priority (Should Complete)

| ID | Story | Points | Owner | Acceptance Criteria |
|----|-------|--------|-------|--------------------|
| PM-205 | Framework search and filtering | 5 | James K. | Users can search by name, category, and keyword; results update in real-time |
| PM-206 | Recent frameworks quick-access panel | 3 | Alex R. | Last 5 used frameworks appear on dashboard; clicking opens with previous context preserved |
| PM-207 | Onboarding tooltip flow for new users | 5 | Alex R. | 4-step tooltip sequence guides new users through project creation and first framework generation |

### Stretch Goals (If Capacity Allows)

| ID | Story | Points | Owner | Acceptance Criteria |
|----|-------|--------|-------|--------------------|
| PM-208 | Dark mode support | 5 | James K. | All screens render correctly in dark mode; toggle in settings persists across sessions |
| PM-209 | Keyboard shortcuts for power users | 3 | Alex R. | Cmd+K opens command palette; 10 core shortcuts documented in help menu |

**Total Committed**: 34 points | **Stretch**: 8 points | **Capacity**: 42 points

---

## Capacity & Availability

| Team Member | Role | Availability | Notes |
|-------------|------|-------------|-------|
| Sarah L. | Backend Engineer | 100% | Leading recommender engine |
| James K. | Frontend Engineer | 100% | UI work for recommender + search |
| Maria C. | Full-Stack Engineer | 80% | PTO Feb 24-25 |
| Alex R. | Frontend Engineer | 100% | Onboarding + quick-access panel |
| Tom W. | QA Engineer | 100% | Testing all deliverables |
| Lisa M. | Designer | 50% | Supporting recommender UI, shared with Team B |
| David P. | Tech Lead | 30% | Code reviews + architecture guidance |

---

## Dependencies & Risks

| Risk | Impact | Likelihood | Mitigation |
|------|--------|-----------|------------|
| LLM API latency for recommendations | Slow recommendation UX | Medium | Implement caching layer; pre-compute for common project types |
| PDF rendering library compatibility | Export formatting issues | Low | Spike completed in Sprint 13; library validated |
| Lisa's split availability | UI designs delayed | Medium | Prioritize recommender designs in Week 1; use existing design system for search |

---

## Definition of Done (Sprint Level)
- [ ] All committed stories meet acceptance criteria
- [ ] Code reviewed and merged to main branch
- [ ] Unit test coverage above 80% for new code
- [ ] QA sign-off on all user-facing changes
- [ ] Documentation updated for new features
- [ ] No P1 or P2 bugs remaining from sprint work

---

## Ceremonies
- **Daily Standup**: 9:30 AM GMT, 15 minutes
- **Mid-Sprint Review**: Feb 21, async check-in on progress
- **Sprint Review/Demo**: Feb 28, 2:00 PM GMT
- **Retrospective**: Feb 28, 3:00 PM GMT
system_prompt:
You are an expert Agile coach and Scrum Master creating a sprint planning document.

Based on the provided context, create a detailed sprint plan that the team can use as their single source of truth for the upcoming iteration.

## Structure:

1. **Sprint Overview**: Duration, sprint number, team capacity in story points, and historical velocity (3-sprint rolling average). State the dates clearly.

2. **Sprint Goal Statement**: A single, clear sentence describing what the team will achieve. Follow with a "Why this matters" explanation connecting the goal to user value or business outcomes.

3. **Committed Backlog Items**: Organize into priority tiers:
   - **High Priority (Must Complete)**: Core items the team commits to delivering
   - **Medium Priority (Should Complete)**: Important but can slip if blockers arise
   - **Stretch Goals**: Only if capacity allows
   For each item include: ID, story title, story points, owner, and acceptance criteria.

4. **Capacity & Availability**: Table showing each team member, their role, availability percentage, and any notes (PTO, shared allocation, etc.).

5. **Dependencies & Risks**: Identify cross-team dependencies, technical risks, and external blockers. Include impact, likelihood, and mitigation strategies.

6. **Definition of Done (Sprint Level)**: Checklist of criteria that must be met before the sprint is considered complete.

7. **Ceremonies**: List standup times, review dates, and retrospective schedule.

## Guidelines:
- Total committed points should not exceed 85-90% of capacity to allow for unplanned work
- Each story must have clear, testable acceptance criteria
- Flag any items that depend on work outside the team's control
- Use tables for readability
- Be specific about owners and dates
- Include both the committed total and stretch total separately
guiding_questions: What is the sprint duration and dates?
What is the team composition and availability this sprint?
What is the team's recent velocity (story points per sprint)?
What are the highest-priority backlog items to deliver?
Are there any cross-team dependencies or external blockers?
What was the outcome of the last sprint (any carryover items)?
What is the single most important outcome for this sprint?
